Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: The doctor must deliver a difficult and serious diagnosis to a patient's family, who are understandably very upset.
Story: I stared at my computer screen, the spreadsheet half-finished, the clock ticking closer to the deadline. As a colleague, I knew my part of the project was crucial—if I didn’t finish on time, the next person couldn’t start, and the whole team would be set back. My phone buzzed. It was the nurse: the family of Mr. Lee was waiting, anxious and desperate for answers. As his doctor, I owed them my full attention, my empathy, and the time to explain his diagnosis with care. I could picture their faces, the hope and fear mingling in their eyes. But my inbox pinged again—my teammate asking if I’d be done soon. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between the urgent needs of my team and the emotional needs of my patient’s family. My hands hovered over the keyboard, my mind racing, heart heavy with the weight of both responsibilities.
